thread.title: Star-studded lineup to honor Sinatra's 100th birthday with TV special
thread.title_full: Star-studded lineup to honor Sinatra's 100th birthday with TV special

author: Bobby Olivier | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Star-studded lineup to honor Sinatra's 100th birthday with TV special
text:
Comments 
A week before what would have been his 100th birthday, the Chairman of the Board will receive a star-studded salute. 
Tony Bennett, John Legend, Alicia Keys and more will honor Jersey legend Frank Sinatra's centennial with "Sinatra 100 â€” An All-Star Grammy Concert," set to air on CBS Dec. 6, The Recording Academy announced Wednesday. 
Also scheduled to perform are less obvious choices to sing Sinatra, including country stars Garth Brooks and Carrie Underwood, Maroon 5 frontman Adam Levine and R&B heartthrob Usher. 
"Frank Sinatra is a voice for all generations," said Neil Portnow, President/CEO of The Recording Academy in a statement. "His showmanship and artistry have remained unmatched since he began performing professionally in the 1930s to his last recording 21 years ago ... it's only fitting that we join the global celebration in honor of his 100th birthday." 
MORE: Check out Hoboken's Sinatra exhibit 
The show will feature arrangements by Don Costa, Gordon Jenkins, Quincy Jones, and Nelson Riddle. 
The huge concert marks the latest celebration of Sinatra's centennial this year, as an exhibit at Lincoln Center in New York was constructed for the singer and actor and open from March through September. Commemorative concerts, books and even an app were formed to celebrate the Hoboken native. 
Sinatra died in 1998, at age 82. He won nine Grammys, including three Album of the Year awards. He would have turned 100 Dec. 12.
